noun.description: A fixed or movable upright partition used to divide a room, give shelter from drafts, heat, or light, or to provide concealment or privacy.
A flat panel or area on an electronic device such as a television, computer, or smartphone, on which images and data are displayed.
A transparent, finely ruled plate or film used in halftone reproduction.
A detachment of troops or ships detailed to cover the movements of the main body.
A large sieve or riddle, especially one for sorting substances such as grain or coal into different sizes.

verb.description: Conceal, protect, or shelter (someone or something) with a screen or something forming a screen.
examples: her hair swung across to screen her face
a high hedge screened all of the front from passersby

verb.description: Show (a movie or video) or broadcast (a television program)
examples: the show is to be screened by HBO later this year

verb.description: Test (a person or substance) for the presence or absence of a disease or contaminant.
examples: outpatients were screened for cervical cancer

verb.description: Pass (a substance such as grain or coal) through a large sieve or screen, especially so as to sort it into different sizes.
Project (a photograph or other image) through a transparent ruled plate so as to be able to reproduce it as a halftone.

origin: Middle English: shortening of Old Northern French escren, of Germanic origin.
